revision.text:
{{Infobox Weapon |is_missile=yes |name=Kh-31
([[NATO reporting name]]: AS-17 'Krypton') |image=[[File:Russian missile -MAKS Airshow 2003.JPG|300px]] |caption=Kh-31A |origin=[[Soviet Union]] |type=Medium-range air-to-surface missile |used_by=Russia, China, India, Algeria |manufacturer=[[Tactical Missiles Corporation]]
(Zvezda-Strela before 2002) |unit_cost= $550 000 (2010)annual report Tactical Missiles Corporation 2010.p. 92 |propellant=kerosene |production_date=1982 |service=1988–present |engine=Solid fuel rocket in initial stage, ramjet for rest of trajectory |weight=Kh-31A :{{convert|610|kg|lb|abbr=on|sigfig=3}}
Kh-31P :{{convert|600|kg|lb|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} |length=Mod 1 : {{convert|4.700|m|ftin|abbr=on}}
Mod 2 (AD/PD) : {{convert|5.3|m|ftin|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=http://eng.ktrv.ru/production_eng/323/512/|title=Tactical Missiles Corporation JSC|publisher=|accessdate=23 December 2014}} |diameter={{convert|360|mm|in|abbr=on}} |wingspan={{convert|914|mm|in|abbr=on}} |speed=Kh-31A/P: {{convert|2160|-|2520|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}
MA-31: Mach 2.7 (low), Mach 3.5 (high) |vehicle_range=Kh-31A: 25 km–103 km (13.5–55.6 [[Nautical mile|nmi]];
Kh-31P: up to {{convert|110|km|nmi mi|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} |filling=HE shaped charge |filling_weight=Kh-31A :{{convert |94|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}}
Kh-31P :{{convert |87|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} |guidance=Kh-31A: [[inertial guidance]] with [[active radar homing]]
Kh-31P: inertial with [[passive radar]] |detonation=Impact |launch_platform=Both : Su-27SM, [[Su-30MKI]], Su-34, Su-35, MiG-29M, [[HAL Tejas]] Mk1 and Mk2, MiG-29K
Kh-31A only : Su-33
Also : Su-24M }} The '''Kh-31''' ({{lang-ru|[[Kha (Cyrillic)|Х]]-31}}; '''AS-17 'Krypton''''){{citation|title=Missiles in the Asia Pacific|url=http://www.ausairpower.net/DT-Missile-Survey-May-05.pdf | journal=Defence Today | publisher=Strike Publications |location=Amberley, Queensland | date=May 2005 | page=67}} is a [[Russia]]n air-to-surface missile carried by aircraft such as the [[MiG-29]] or [[Su-27]]. It is capable of [[Mach number|Mach]] 3.5 and was the first supersonic anti-ship missile that could be launched by tactical aircraft.{{citation | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=4S3h8j_NEmkC&pg=PA534 | title=The Naval Institute Guide to World Naval Weapon Systems | first= Norman | last=Friedman | pages=534–5 | edition=5th | publisher=Naval Institute Press |year=2006 | isbn=978-1-55750-262-9}} There are several variants, it is best known as an [[anti-radiation missile]] (ARM) but there are also anti-shipping and target drone versions. There has been talk of adapting it to make an "AWACS killer", a long-range air-to-air missile. ==Development== The proliferation of [[surface-to-air missile]]s (SAMs) has made the [[Suppression of Enemy Air Defence]] a priority for any modern air force intending offensive action. Knocking out air search radars and [[fire control radar]]s is an essential part of this mission. ARMs must have [[standoff (missile)|sufficient range]] that the launch platform is out of range of the SAMs, high speed to reduce the risk of being shot down and a seeker that can detect a range of radar types, but they do not need a particularly big warhead. The Soviet Union's first ARM was developed by the Raduga OKB engineering group responsible for the Soviet Union's missiles for heavy bombers. The Kh-22P was developed from the 6-tonne [[Raduga Kh-22]] (AS-4 'Kitchen') missile. Experience gained with this led in 1973 to the [[Kh-28]] (AS-9 'Kyle') carried by tactical aircraft such as the [[Su-7]]B, [[Su-17]] and [[Su-24]]. It had Mach 3 capability and a {{convert|120|km|nmi|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} range, greater than the contemporary [[AGM-78 Standard ARM]]. The Kh-28 was succeeded by the [[Kh-58]] in 1978, which has similar speed and range but replaces the dual-fuel rocket motor with a much safer RDTT solid propellant. The development of more sophisticated SAMs such as the [[MIM-104 Patriot]] and the US Navy's [[Aegis combat system]] put pressure on the Soviets to develop better ARMs in turn.{{cite web |url=http://www.uscc.gov/researchpapers/2000_2003/pdfs/strat.pdf |title=China's Military Strategy Toward the U.S. |publisher=www.uscc.gov}}{{cite web |url=http://www.carnegieendowment.org/pdf/npp/CRSchinamissilesupdated081000.pdf |title=CRS Report for Congress, China: Ballistic and Cruise Missiles| publisher=www.carnegieendowment.org |date=2000-08-10|accessdate=2007-01-26}} Zvezda came at the problem from a different angle to Raduga, having a background in lightweight air-to-air missiles. However, in the mid-1970s they had developed the successful [[Kh-25]] family of short-range air-to-surface missiles, including the Kh-25MP ([[AS-12 Kegler|AS-12 'Kegler']]) for [[anti-radar]] use. Zvezda started work on a long-range ARM and the first launch of the Kh-31 was in 1982. It entered service in 1988{{Citation needed | date=January 2009}} and was first displayed in public in 1991, the Kh-31P at Dubai and the Kh-31A at Minsk. In December 1997 it was reported that a small number of Kh-31's had been delivered to China, but that "production had yet to begin".{{citation|title=China and Russia combine on KR-1 | first=Douglas | last=Barrie | url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1997/1997%20-%203365.html |magazine=Flight International | date=1997-12-10 | page=17}} It was around this time that the Russians sold [[Su-30MKK]] 'Flanker-G' aircraft to the Chinese. It seems that the original deliveries were of the original Russian model designated as X-31, to allow testing whilst the KR-1 model was being developed for licence production.{{citation|url=http://www.janes.com/articles/Janes-Defence-Weekly-98/RUSSIA--AS-17-KRYPTON-KH-31.html | title=Russia: - AS-17 Krypton (Kh-31) | journal=Jane's Defence Weekly | date=1998-09-09 | accessdate=2009-01-27}} Local production may have started by July 2005. Russian development has accelerated since Zvezda was subsumed into the Tactical Missiles Corporation in 2002, with the announcement of the 'D' extended range models and the 'M' model mid-life updates (see Variants section below). ==Design== [[File:Seeker of Kh-31 missile.jpg|thumb|L112E seeker]] In many respects the Kh-31 is a miniaturised version of the P-270 [[P-270 Moskit|Moskit]] (SS-N-22 'Sunburn') and was reportedly designed by the same man. The missile is conventionally shaped, with cruciform wings and control surfaces made from titanium. The two-stage propulsion is notable. On launch, a solid-fuel booster in the tail accelerates the missile to Mach 1.8 and the motor is discarded. Then four air intakes open up and as in the Franco-German ANS/ANF the empty rocket case becomes the combustion chamber of a kerosene-fuelled [[ramjet]], which takes it beyond Mach 4. The L-111E seeker of the anti-radar version has a unique antenna, an [[interferometer]] array of seven spiral antennas on a steerable platform. The seekers delivered to China in 2001-2 were {{convert|106.5|cm|in|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|36|cm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter, and weighed {{convert|23|kg|lb|abbr=on}}.{{citation|title=China may be producing Kh-31P ARM |url=http://www.janes.com/extract/jmr2005/jmr01502.html |journal=Jane's Missiles and Rockets |date=2005-07-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202043721/http://www.janes.com/extract/jmr2005/jmr01502.html |archivedate=February 2, 2009 }} ==Operational history== The Kh-31P ARM entered service in Russia in 1988 and the Kh-31A anti-shipping version in 1989. Unlike its predecessors, it can be fitted to almost any of Russia's tactical aircraft, from the [[Su-17]] to [[MiG-31]]. A few Kh-31P/KR-1's were delivered to China in 1997 but these were apparently for testing and development work. The Chinese ordered Russian missiles in late 2002 or early 2003, leading to 200 KR-1's in their inventory by 2005; the Chinese press reported in July 2005 that Su-30MKK's of the 3rd Air Division had been equipped with the missiles. In 2001 India bought Kh-31s for its [[Su-30MKI]]; they appear to have bought 60 Kh-31A and 90 Kh-31P. The [[US Navy]] bought [[MA-31]] target drones. An $18.468-million order for thirty-four MA-31 was placed in 1999,{{citation|url=http://www.defenselink.mil/contracts/contract.aspx?contractid=1670|title=Contracts for Thursday, December 16, 1999 | publisher=US Department of Defense | date=1999-12-16}} but this order was blocked by the Russians.Buckley 2007 The MA-31 was launched from an [[F-4 Phantom]], and work was done on a kit to launch it from an F-16.{{citation | url=http://www.dtic.mil/ndia/2004rangeops/17Nov04/Braucksick.ppt | title=MA-31 Target Vehicle OVERVIEW | first=Ken |last=Braucksick | date=2004-11-17 | publisher=NDIA}}. Sales pitch from Boeing, has useful diagrams of flight profiles etc According to some reports, the missile was used by the Russian Air Force during the South Ossetian conflict in 2008. In particular, reported that in the August 10, 2008 a Russian Air Force Su-34 struck with [[anti-radar missile]]s Kh-31P an [[air defense radar]] of Georgia near the city of Gori, then Georgian air defense was disabled in order to avoid further losses.{{cite web|url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/tech/news/2009/12/21/912023|title=- -34|work=Vedomosti.ru|accessdate=23 December 2014}} ==Variants== [[File:R-27T Kh 59ME Kh-31P.jpg|310px|thumb|Kh-31P (right) with [[Vympel R-27|R-27]] (left) and [[Kh-59]] (middle) at [[MAKS Airshow]], [[Zhukovskiy (city)|Zhukovskiy]], 1999]] * '''Kh-31A''' - active seeker head for use as an anti-shipping missile against vessels up to destroyer size, range of 25 km–103 km (13.5–55.6 [[Nautical mile|nmi]]).{{citation | title=AEROSPACE SYSTEMS export catalogue | url=http://www.rusarm.ru/cataloque/air_craft/aircraft.pdf | publisher=Rosoboronexport State Corporation | last=Rosoboronexport Air Force Department and Media & PR Service}} Missile is sea-skimming as it approaches the target. * '''Kh-31P''' (Type 77P) - passive seeker head for use as an anti-radiation missile. Stays at high altitude throughout its flight, allowing higher speeds and increasing range to {{convert|110|km|nmi mi|abbr=on|sigfig=1}}. The seeker has three interchangeable modules to cover different radar [[frequency band]]s, but they can only be changed at the factory.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} * '''Kh-31AD'''/'''Kh-31PD''' ("'''Kh-31 Mod 2'''") - increase range through increasing the fuselage from {{convert|4.70|m|ftin|abbr=on}} to {{convert|5.3|m|ftin|abbr=on}} long.{{cite web|url=http://www.ktrv.ru/production/68/673/|title=ОАО "Корпорация Тактическое Ракетное Вооружение"|publisher=|accessdate=23 December 2014}} As of 2012, the Kh-31PD is serially produced.{{cite web|url=http://vpk.name/news/74976_korporaciya_takticheskoe_raketnoe_vooruzhenie_nachala_seriinoe_proizvodstvo_prr_x31pd.html|title=Корпорация "Тактическое ракетное вооружение" начала серийное производство ПРР X-31ПД|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2015}} Kh-31AD is in series production since 2013.{{cite web|url=http://vpk.name/news/95829_boris_obnosov_rossiya_v_blizhaishie_dva_goda_nachnet_eksport_dvuh_tipov_raket_klassa_vozduhpoverhnost.html|title=: -|publisher=|accessdate=23 December 2014}} * '''Kh-31PK''' - installed non-contact fuse, maximum speed 900 m/s, range 120-160 km. Destined for Su-27SM, Su-30MK, Su-35. In serial production since 2009.http://vpk.name/news/31600_trv_vyipuskaet_protivoradiolokacionnuyu_raketu_h31pk.html * '''[[MA-31]]''' - telemetry and other systems installed by McDonnell Douglas/Boeing for use by the US Navy as a target drone. Tested between 1996-2007;{{citation|url=http://www.dtic.mil/ndia/2007targets/Day2/PatBuckley/Buckleynovideo.pdf | title=U.S. Navy Aerial Target Systems (Presented to 45th Annual NDIA Symposium) | last=Buckley | first=Capt. Pat | date=2007-10-31 | publisher=US Navy}} a version upgraded with GPS, the MA-31PG, was offered to the Navy as a replacement for the [[MQM-8 Vandal]] but they bought the [[GQM-163 Coyote]]. Even with the additional equipment, the MA-31 was capable of Mach 2.7 and 15G manoevres in its anti-ship (sea-skimming) flight profile and Mach 3.5 in ARM mode at {{convert|48000|ft|m|abbr=on}}. * '''KR-1''' - version of the Kh-31P exported to China in 1997. It seems that Zvezda wanted to sell an initial batch of KR-1's to China, before the KR-1 went into production in China. Rather than the original three seeker modules, the KR-1 has a single K-112E "export" seeker targeting [[D band (NATO)|D]]-[[F band (NATO)|F band]] ([[S band]]) emissions, and reportedly optimised for specific Taiwanese radars. * '''[[YJ-91]]''' ''Ying Ji 91'' - Chinese missile based on the Kh-31P, with faster speed, slightly longer range, and easier switching of seeker heads.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} They are also reported to have developed an anti-shipping version with an indigenous active seeker, and are looking to develop this for use in submarines. The name YJ-91 was already in use by 1997, and may have been a Chinese name for the original Russian missiles designated X-31 by the Russians. By 2005, the name '''YJ-93''' was being applied to missiles made in China, but Western reports generally do not distinguish between YJ-91 and YJ-93. An active/passive air-to-air version for use against slow-moving support aircraft, a so-called "AWACS killer", was announced at the 1992 [[MAKS Airshow|Moscow air show]] with {{convert|200|km|nmi mi|abbr=on}} range. That would be less than the {{convert|300|-|400|km|nmi mi}} promised by the [[Vympel R-37]] (AA-13 'Arrow') and Novator [[R-172]] missiles, but a Kh-31 derivative could be carried by a wider range of aircraft. However this may have been mere propaganda; in 2004 the Tactical Missiles Corporation "emphatically denied" that it had ever worked on an air-to-air version of the Kh-31.{{citation|url=http://www.janes.com/articles/Janes-Air-Launched-Weapons/Kh-31-AS-17-Russian-Federation.html | title=Kh-31 (AS-17) (Russian Federation), Air-to-air Missiles - Beyond Visual Range | journal=Jane's Air-Launched Weapons| date=2004-11-18| accessdate=2009-01-27}} In 2005 rumours persisted of a Russian AWACS killer based on the Kh-31A anti-shipping model, and of the Chinese adapting the YJ-91, derived from the Kh-31P, for the same purpose. ==Operators== [[File:Kh-31 operators.png|thumb|400px|Map with Kh-31 operators in blue]] ===Current operators=== * {{RUS}} '''222''': 2009 delivered 147, 2010 delivered 75 Kh-31 * {{ALG}} '''125'''http://armstrade.sipri.org/armstrade/page/trade_register.php delivered in 2007-2009 * {{SYR}} '''87''' delivered in 2008-2010annual report Tactical Missiles Corporation 2009.p. 77 * {{IND}} * {{CHN}} * {{IDN}}2011 Annual Report of Tactical Missile Corporation, http://bmpd.livejournal.com/290141.html * {{PER}} * {{VEN}} * {{VNM}} * {{MAS}} ; Potential operators * {{PRK}} * {{IRN}} ===Former operators=== * {{USSR}} ==See also== * [[DRDO Anti-Radiation Missile]] * [[YJ-91]] - Chinese missile based on Kh-31 * [[P-270 Moskit]] (SS-N-22 'Sunburn') * [[AGM-88 HARM]] - main US anti-radiation missile * [[ALARM missile]] - British ARM with loiter capability * [[MAR-1]] - Brazilian ARM project * [[AGM-136 Tacit Rainbow]] - US ARM cancelled in 1991 ==Notes== {{commons category|Kh-31}} {{Reflist}} ==References== * {{Citation|last=Gordon|first=Yefim|title=Soviet/Russian Aircraft Weapons Since World War Two|year=2004|location=Hinckley, England|publisher=Midland Publishing|isbn=1-85780-188-1}} {{Russian and Soviet missiles|ASM}} [[Category:Anti-radiation missiles of Russia|Kh-031]] [[Category:Anti-radiation missiles of the Soviet Union|Kh-031]] [[Category:Cold War air-to-surface missiles of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Air-to-surface missiles of Russia|Kh-031]] [[Category:Air-to-surface missiles of the Soviet Union|Kh-031]] [[Category:Anti-radiation missiles]]
